discussion.content: Why C is not correct?

choices.F: Object privileges granted on a table automatically apply to all synonyms for that table.
choices.E: Only users with the GRANT ANY PRIVILEGE privilege can grant and revoke system privileges from other users.
choices.C: Schema owners can grant object privileges on objects in their schema to any other user or role.
choices.B: All types of schema objects have associated object privileges.
choices.D: Only users with the DBA role can create roles.
choices.A: A combination of object and system privileges can be granted to a role.

questions.question_text: Which three are true about privileges? (Choose three.)
Which two statements are true about TRUNCATE and DELETE? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A. DELETE can use a WHERE clause to determine which row(s) should be removed. ---> Is correct
B. TRUNCATE can use a WHERE clause to determine which row(s) should be removed. ---> Its wrong bcoz truncate will delete every rows in a table except the table definitions.
C. TRUNCATE leaves any indexes on the table in an UNUSABLE state. ----> its wrong truncate will remove everything except table definition or skeleton of the table
D. The result of a TRUNCATE can be undone by issuing a ROLLBACK.-----> Its wrong bcoz TRUNCATE is a ddl statement whereas it can be done for DELETE since its dml statement
E. The result of a DELETE can be undone by issuing a ROLLBACK. ----> Its correct bcoz DELETE is DML statement and each delete of row are recorded in transaction log or the redo logs.

Selected Answer: AE
We can use WHERE clause in DELETE, We can ROLLBACK DELETE operation.

Selected Answer: AE
Truncate is forever...

Selected Answer: AE
A, E correct answers

AE
is the correct ans.
With truncate we can not user where clause (B)
with truncate even if we rollback data will not be rollback. (D)
AE correct answers
AE are the correct answers

choices.C: TRUNCATE leaves any indexes on the table in an UNUSABLE state.
choices.A: DELETE can use a WHERE clause to determine which row(s) should be removed.
choices.E: The result of a DELETE can be undone by issuing a ROLLBACK.
choices.D: The result of a TRUNCATE can be undone by issuing a ROLLBACK.
choices.B: TRUNCATE can use a WHERE clause to determine which row(s) should be removed.
